value.title: All in One Script to Create Calendar Table or Date Dimension using DAX in Power BI
value.excerpt: I have previously written an article with the full script of how to generate a date dimension in Power BI using the Power Query script, and I would always recommend that as the first choice. However, sometimes, you just want this to be in DAX way, so here in this blog and video, I explained how to create
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zeXQknz4RdI" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Basics of DAX Expression in Power BI
value.excerpt: There are a lot of resources about how to use each function. However, you always need to start with learning how the expression language works itself. You need to learn how to reference columns, and tables. what operators can be used, and what are the very simple basics of writing a DAX expression. In
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/GVAzp-YICnQ" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Create a subset of the table in Power BI and add calculations using SELECTCOLUMNS DAX Function
value.excerpt: Previously I explained the AddColumns function as a function that adds one or more columns to the existing table, In this article and video, I'll explain another similar and useful function with slightly different behavior: SelectColumns, and you will learn how you can use it in Power BI and DAX. Download

value.title: Creating Calendar Table in Power BI using DAX Functions
value.excerpt: I have previously explained about using Power Query for creating calendar tables, However, some people still love to do that in DAX. There are a couple of DAX functions which makes the process of creating a calendar table very simple and easy; Calendar() and CalendarAuto(). In this short video, I'll

value.title: Customers Grouped by the Count of their Orders – Dynamic Segmentation in Power BI Using DAX Measures
value.excerpt: In the previous part of this video, I explained what is the segmentation challenge, when you want to group data based on the aggregated result, and I explained a static method of creating aggregated tables and creating a relationship to the main detailed table. However, the caveat of that method is the
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bRk0tofVn2c" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: DAX Measure in the Axis of the Power BI Report
value.excerpt: If you even need to show your DAX measures in a chart without a dimension to slice and dice it, you won’t get a great experience in the visual. In this video, I’ll share a trick that you can use to have a nice visualization like what you see in the above screenshot. Download the file and study more from
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CRs2CnW7tVU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Dynamic Banding or Grouping in Power BI – Using DAX Measures – Choose the Size of Bins
value.excerpt: In the previous video, I explained how to create dynamic bins by choosing the count of bins in a slicer in the Power BI report. In this video, I'll explain, how you can do it the other way around, which is by selecting the size of the bin, you will have bins and buckets dynamically generated. Download
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cbxVCa5lAcw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Find a Text Term in a Field in Power BI Using DAX Functions
value.excerpt: In Power BI, there are multiple ways of searching for a text term inside a text field, you can use Power Query for doing this operation or calculations in DAX. In this video, I'll explain some functions in DAX that you can use to do this calculation. Most of these functions can be used inside a measure

value.title: Power BI DAX RelatedTable Function   Get the subtable related to the current row
value.excerpt: There are multiple functions that can help when you work with tables that are connected through relationships. One of these functions is Relatedtable. This function gives you the subtable from the other table for all the rows related to the current row. For example, all sales transactions (from the Sales
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZrhnliV7Jrw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Power BI Modeling Tip   Snapshot Table or DAX Measures
value.excerpt: I often get this question: “Is it better that I create this calculation as a snapshot table in Power Query (or T-SQL, or the data source), or write DAX measures for it?” If you ever had a scenario of creating a report of snapshots, you know what I mean. “Should I have a table for inventory stock on hand

value.title: Computing a measure in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: You can use DAX Studio to evaluate one or more measures in your data model. This is the first step to write, test, and debug your DAX measures in a productive manner.  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/kAniA_N7sB8" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Evaluation of variables in DAX
value.excerpt: Variables in DAX are constants, and this could be very confusing! Watch this video to understand how the evaluation of variables works in DAX. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ The definitive guide to DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/books/the-definitive-guide-to-dax-2nd-edition/

value.title: Filtering a measure in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: DAX Studio can evaluate one or more measures in a query. Marco Russo shows how to apply filters to a measure executed in DAX Studio. Continuous learning to improve your productivity!  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: How to debug a DAX measure

value.title: Introducing Performance Analyzer in Power BI Desktop
value.excerpt: Performance Analyzer is the first diagnostic tool to find the slower parts of a report. Find the slowest DAX query before starting a deeper investigation using DAX Studio. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Mark as Date Table in Power BI
value.excerpt: Tabular models (including Power BI) require marking the Date table as a date table to get appropriate results with time intelligence calculations. This video explains why this setting is required. Article and download: https://sql.bi/670749
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hrhEjg9yYvE" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Optimizing duplicated DAX expressions using variables
value.excerpt: This video describes how to use variables to optimize the performance of DAX expressions containing multiple instances of the same measure or the same sub-expression. There are two related articles and downloads: https://sql.bi/62887/?aff=yt (Optimizing duplicated DAX expressions using variables) https://sql.bi/67786/?aff=yt

value.title: Sorting months in fiscal calendars in DAX
value.excerpt: This video shows a basic technique used to sort months according to a fiscal calendar, by using a couple of calculated columns and the “sort by column” feature of Power BI. Article and download: https://sql.bi/492713?aff=yt

value.title: Understanding Performance Analyzer metrics in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: Performance Analyzer metrics imported in DAX Studio provide many details not available in Power BI Desktop. Learn the meaning of each number and how to use them to find report bottlenecks. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Build a P&L in Power BI Without Any DAX
value.excerpt: This is the third article where I have covered building a P&L in Power BI. My first 2 articles here and here focused on how to use the DAX language to solve some of the common problems with P&L reporting, such as adding sub totals into the visual, % of [...]Read More »

value.title: Introduction to Power BI and DAX
value.excerpt: Back in 2019 I ran a free webinar introducing Power BI and DAX. Many readers of my blog will already be well ahead of this topic, but then again many of you also probably run into people who would benefits from a simple introduction. I have decided to publish the [...]Read More »
